channel.title: Scripting News
channel.description: It's even worse than it appears..

item.description: Poll: Have you had Covid?

source:outline.text: Poll: Have you had Covid?

item.description: I can’t believe reporters keep holding material evidence secret to promote their books. And other reporters let them slide. With glee. What a racket.

source:outline.text: I can’t believe reporters keep holding material evidence secret to promote their books. And other reporters let them slide. With glee. What a racket.

item.description: We should just discount the president's approval rating down to zero and then we could view 39% as a historic high. But seriously folks, the president's approval rating is just how the news, as it's reported, bounces off the minds of the people the pollsters talk to. You could model it like they model weather reports, and tune up the news coverage to create any approval rating you want.

source:outline.text: We should just discount the president's approval rating down to zero and then we could view 39% as a historic high. But seriously folks, the president's approval rating is just how the news, as it's reported, bounces off the minds of the people the pollsters talk to. You could model it like they model weather reports, and tune up the news coverage to create any approval rating you want.

item.description: After reading this Wikipedia article I still don’t understand what “full stop” means. Instead of saying “full stop” couldn’t you just stop?

item.description: The big problem isn't climate change, it's getting people to work together instead of just working for themselves. And to start working together we have to learn how to listen. It's hard, when we're raised to not listen.

source:outline.text: The big problem isn't climate change, it's getting people to work together instead of just working for themselves. And to start working together we have to learn how to listen. It's hard, when we're raised to not listen.

item.description: I watched a tiny bit of the French presidential debate yesterday and what struck me is how civil they were with each other, compared to US politics.

source:outline.text: I watched a tiny bit of the French presidential debate yesterday and what struck me is how civil they were with each other, compared to US politics.

item.description: BTW, my plan is to hook RSS up to any protocol people come up with. And when I say RSS, I mean all flavors including RDF and Atom. I don't just have advice for other people, sometimes I give myself advice too. I think it's time to love RSS again. ❤️

source:outline.text: BTW, my plan is to hook RSS up to any protocol people come up with. And when I say RSS, I mean all flavors including RDF and Atom. I don't just have advice for other people, sometimes I give myself advice too. I think it's time to love RSS again. ❤️

item.description: I adore the current Jeopardy champion Mattea Roach. Actually I adore them all. They are amazing people. Not only do they have great memory, but think about all the things they know. I also think Ken Jennings is the obvious best choice to be the Jeopardy host because he's such a great Jeopardy player, is immersed in all aspects of the game and he really connects with the players, and therefore the fans at home. They are all such wonderful unabashed nerds. I've been watching the show since I was a kid, when Art Fleming was the host, when I watched it with my mom.

source:outline.text: I adore the current Jeopardy champion Mattea Roach. Actually I adore them all. They are amazing people. Not only do they have great memory, but think about all the things they know. I also think Ken Jennings is the obvious best choice to be the Jeopardy host because he's such a great Jeopardy player, is immersed in all aspects of the game and he really connects with the players, and therefore the fans at home. They are all such wonderful unabashed nerds. I've been watching the show since I was a kid, when Art Fleming was the host, when I watched it with my mom.

item.description: Yes, I do edit my JavaScript code in an outliner. A few years ago I started including the OPML source in my GitHub projects. Look for source.opml. It has the source for all the files in the project in one file. Example.

source:outline.text: Yes, I do edit my JavaScript code in an outliner. A few years ago I started including the OPML source in my GitHub projects. Look for source.opml. It has the source for all the files in the project in one file. Example.

item.description: We're curing ourselves from Covid the way people who smoke while they quit smoking aren't actually quitting. To quit, you stop. If you take your masks off, that's like buying a pack of cigarettes, and having one or two and then finishing the pack and then getting another. I speak as an ex-smoker for over 30 years. I had all kinds of plans for quitting, but the only way to do it is to quit. We'll never get out of the Covid hole until all of us commit to it and then follow through. Otherwise it's going to continue to be a lingering tragedy.

source:outline.text: We're curing ourselves from Covid the way people who smoke while they quit smoking aren't actually quitting. To quit, you stop. If you take your masks off, that's like buying a pack of cigarettes, and having one or two and then finishing the pack and then getting another. I speak as an ex-smoker for over 30 years. I had all kinds of plans for quitting, but the only way to do it is to quit. We'll never get out of the Covid hole until all of us commit to it and then follow through. Otherwise it's going to continue to be a lingering tragedy.

item.description: I'm going to continue to wear a mask when I go out in public. My face feels naked without it. The other day I went into the supermarket without a mask and had to go back out to the car to get one. In that moment I got to think about why I wear a mask even when others aren't. It's because I want to send a message to my fellow shoppers that I care about their health. I was raised to be a considerate person. So many people were raised to be self-centered and pissy. I never want to see myself that way. Anyway it was really annoying how quickly the airlines took down their mask requirements. I suggest if you want to make your feelings known to them, stop flying until they bring the mandates back.

The other day I went into the supermarket without a mask and had to go back out to the car to get one. In that moment I got to think about why I wear a mask even when others aren't. It's because I want to send a message to my fellow shoppers that I care about their health. I was raised to be a considerate person. So many people were raised to be self-centered and pissy. I never want to see myself that way. Anyway it was really annoying how quickly the airlines took down their mask requirements. I suggest if you want to make your feelings known to them, stop flying until they bring the mandates back.

item.description: We're going to need curated lists of feeds, like people do curated lists of Twitter users. If we're going to make the most of the coming reboot of RSS, we should be prepared to help people get the immediate benefit without doing a lot of upfront work. Having wonderfully thoughtful collections of feeds, based on real expertise, would be a great welcome wagon for new users. I can help with the presentation.

source:outline.text: We're going to need curated lists of feeds, like people do curated lists of Twitter users. If we're going to make the most of the coming reboot of RSS, we should be prepared to help people get the immediate benefit without doing a lot of upfront work. Having wonderfully thoughtful collections of feeds, based on real expertise, would be a great welcome wagon for new users. I can help with the presentation.

item.description: OMG -- two episodes of Better Call Saul tonight, and three NBA playoff games. I have never been so gifted by quality entertainment. And my software development is going well, last week's stagnation has given way to this week's steady progress. I needed a break obviously.

item.title: Site licenses
item.description:
In 1986, my little software company was in a weird place.

We had a great product almost ready to ship for the Mac. Everyone was psyched, MacUser and MacWorld, the people inside Apple, the people we leaked it to in the industry. But we were broke, couldn't make payroll.

My board was tired of the roller coaster, they told me to shut the company down. I told them they were crazy, we're sitting on the best product anyone has ever made, and the market is totally ready for it. The Mac was finally selling in huge numbers, after they fixed all the problems, and most other software devs were shutting down their mac development in the year before, we were going to have the booming mac software market virtually to ourselves.

No deal. The board wouldn't put up the $400K we needed to get to shipping the product. So I went to my best friend at Apple, and told him what was going on. We were going to have to shut down before shipping the product you want so badly. I begged for their help. Man did they help us.

First they gave us the money we needed to stay open as a loan. We had to put the source code to the product in escrow. We also did a second deal. They bought a site license for the product, everyone at Apple would get a copy, and in return they'd give us 40 new Mac systems with lots of memory, printers, networking. And they gave us 10 more Macs to give to our board members, which was also really smart. None of them had Macs.

The reason I told this story is the power of the site license. I would have paid them all to use the product, because once the hardware company is standardizing on your product, you'll never go out of business as long as they're in business. And the inverse was true too. If we all had Macs maybe we'd stop thinking about making software for PCs. Back then Apple had guts and smarts. Quite a combo. Probably because they too had gone through tough times and were emerging from them.

It was the best year of my life in the software world, and I've had some good years. ;-)

source:outline.text: Site licenses
In 1986, my little software company was in a weird place.

We had a great product almost ready to ship for the Mac. Everyone was psyched, MacUser and MacWorld, the people inside Apple, the people we leaked it to in the industry. But we were broke, couldn't make payroll.

My board was tired of the roller coaster, they told me to shut the company down. I told them they were crazy, we're sitting on the best product anyone has ever made, and the market is totally ready for it. The Mac was finally selling in huge numbers, after they fixed all the problems, and most other software devs were shutting down their mac development in the year before, we were going to have the booming mac software market virtually to ourselves.

No deal. The board wouldn't put up the $400K we needed to get to shipping the product. So I went to my best friend at Apple, and told him what was going on. We were going to have to shut down before shipping the product you want so badly. I begged for their help. Man did they help us.

First they gave us the money we needed to stay open as a loan. We had to put the source code to the product in escrow. We also did a second deal. They bought a site license for the product, everyone at Apple would get a copy, and in return they'd give us 40 new Mac systems with lots of memory, printers, networking. And they gave us 10 more Macs to give to our board members, which was also really smart. None of them had Macs.

The reason I told this story is the power of the site license. I would have paid them all to use the product, because once the hardware company is standardizing on your product, you'll never go out of business as long as they're in business. And the inverse was true too. If we all had Macs maybe we'd stop thinking about making software for PCs. Back then Apple had guts and smarts. Quite a combo. Probably because they too had gone through tough times and were emerging from them.
It was the best year of my life in the software world, and I've had some good years. ;-)

item.description: From watching Severance twice, I now know why, when Helly goes out through the exit, trying to escape, she immediately comes back through the same door she went out from. It wasn't metaphysical. There's a simple explanation for it.

source:outline.text: From watching Severance twice, I now know why, when Helly goes out through the exit, trying to escape, she immediately comes back through the same door she went out from. It wasn't metaphysical. There's a simple explanation for it.

item.description: Tell someone they did something good, or they look nice, or they're a great friend. Or give them something nice to eat. I just realized it's so rare that we do this. Everyone's looking for a nice word of praise or reassurance. We treat our pets better than our human friends.

source:outline.text: Tell someone they did something good, or they look nice, or they're a great friend. Or give them something nice to eat. I just realized it's so rare that we do this. Everyone's looking for a nice word of praise or reassurance. We treat our pets better than our human friends.

item.title: A more concise brain dump
item.description:
Key point -- Twitter has been going nowhere for its whole life, just drifting, aimlessly.

The companies Musk leads do not drift. They create amazing products that change things.

The way we need Twitter to change.

Here's the full thread.

source:outline.text: A more concise brain dump
Key point -- Twitter has been going nowhere for its whole life, just drifting, aimlessly.
The companies Musk leads do not drift. They create amazing products that change things.
The way we need Twitter to change.
Here's the full thread.

item.title: Let a thousand Twitters bloom
item.description:
A rambling brain dump about Twitter and Musk.

Self-moderation is going to be a huge deal. Maybe something like self-driving Teslas. Which the driver controls, btw. It isn't a passive thing. If a Musk company can do that, yeah I think they can give users more control over the bullshit they have to deal with on Twitter. The thing is Twitter has been stuck since 2006 when it started. They hired people to make the system run reliably, which is fantastic, hat's off, but it needs a few more things to be able to realizae its potential as a world-scale notification system for all kinds of networked writing.

Maybe to make something workable you have to start something new, not in a half assed way.. Or maybe a no-bullshit capitalist like Musk can make it come about from the chaos of Twitter.

Most people have no idea how software works and is made.

A Twitter-like webservice at AWS. With better docs and a JavaScript API that doesn't require developer to run a server (big deal). Effortless install on Digital Ocean.

Let a thousand Twitters bloom.

Interop baked in from the beginning.

Look, Elon made buying a car a completely online experience, moving around huge amounts of money and metal and an explosion in demand. Buying a Tesla was like buying a Mac in 1984 or an iPhone in 2007, except they're doing it 365 days a year for years. And buying a StarLink is just as easy and just as much of a sensation. If this is easy to do why do so few companies do it?

BTW, if Musk was trying to buy my bank, I'd be all for it. That's how bad their software is. All banks have shit software, btw, near as I can tell.

Seriously, if you think he can't run Twitter when he can run StarLink and Tesla, please. And why should Twitter be stuck in the mud like it has been since inception. It desperately needs some fixes, and at a minumum must be made easier to peer with. Developers can do all the work if they just add a few simple features that they probably already have implemented.

I was an Apple dev in 1997 when Jobs came back. Musk is like Jobs in that he won't be scared to make the big changes that are needed.

We're lucky a guy like Musk is hanging around and willing to take on this job.

And as usual the journalists see a teeny little corner of the picture and are screaming about that.

A rambling brain dump about Twitter and Musk.

Self-moderation is going to be a huge deal. Maybe something like self-driving Teslas. Which the driver controls, btw. It isn't a passive thing. If a Musk company can do that, yeah I think they can give users more control over the bullshit they have to deal with on Twitter. The thing is Twitter has been stuck since 2006 when it started. They hired people to make the system run reliably, which is fantastic, hat's off, but it needs a few more things to be able to realizae its potential as a world-scale notification system for all kinds of networked writing.
Maybe to make something workable you have to start something new, not in a half assed way.. Or maybe a no-bullshit capitalist like Musk can make it come about from the chaos of Twitter.
Most people have no idea how software works and is made.
A Twitter-like webservice at AWS. With better docs and a JavaScript API that doesn't require developer to run a server (big deal). Effortless install on Digital Ocean.
Let a thousand Twitters bloom.
Interop baked in from the beginning.

Look, Elon made buying a car a completely online experience, moving around huge amounts of money and metal and an explosion in demand. Buying a Tesla was like buying a Mac in 1984 or an iPhone in 2007, except they're doing it 365 days a year for years. And buying a StarLink is just as easy and just as much of a sensation. If this is easy to do why do so few companies do it?
BTW, if Musk was trying to buy my bank, I'd be all for it. That's how bad their software is. All banks have shit software, btw, near as I can tell.

Seriously, if you think he can't run Twitter when he can run StarLink and Tesla, please. And why should Twitter be stuck in the mud like it has been since inception. It desperately needs some fixes, and at a minumum must be made easier to peer with. Developers can do all the work if they just add a few simple features that they probably already have implemented.
I was an Apple dev in 1997 when Jobs came back. Musk is like Jobs in that he won't be scared to make the big changes that are needed.
We're lucky a guy like Musk is hanging around and willing to take on this job.
And as usual the journalists see a teeny little corner of the picture and are screaming about that.

item.description: Bertha may be the best song to Peloton to. "That's why, if you please, Bertha don't you come round here any more."

source:outline.text: Bertha may be the best song to Peloton to. "That's why, if you please, Bertha don't you come round here any more."

item.description: Like many fans of the Grateful Dead I thought Bertha was about a fan in the Dead office named Bertha, but it's the other way around, the fan was given the name of the song. On the other hand, the Beatles song, Martha My Dear is about Paul McCartney's Old English Sheepdog Martha. Speaking of McCartney, I learned recently that he co-wrote the fantastic Elvis Costello song Veronica. It's definitely got the McCartney feel to it, another spin perhaps on Eleanor Rigby, which is not a good song to Peloton to, btw, imho.

source:outline.text: Like many fans of the Grateful Dead I thought Bertha was about a fan in the Dead office named Bertha, but it's the other way around, the fan was given the name of the song. On the other hand, the Beatles song, Martha My Dear is about Paul McCartney's Old English Sheepdog Martha. Speaking of McCartney, I learned recently that he co-wrote the fantastic Elvis Costello song Veronica. It's definitely got the McCartney feel to it, another spin perhaps on Eleanor Rigby, which is not a good song to Peloton to, btw, imho.

item.description: I love all the Beatles songs, but get the most, these days, out of John Lennon's songs. I learned that Lennon only partially completed his songs, leaving a lot of the work to George Martin. Keep that in mind when you listen to I Am The Walrus (my favorite Beatles song) and Strawberry Fields, as examples. The orchestral bits are pure Martin.

source:outline.text: I love all the Beatles songs, but get the most, these days, out of John Lennon's songs. I learned that Lennon only partially completed his songs, leaving a lot of the work to George Martin. Keep that in mind when you listen to I Am The Walrus (my favorite Beatles song) and Strawberry Fields, as examples. The orchestral bits are pure Martin.

item.description: I have the best search engine for a blog. I'm sure there's better search software out there, but no one else has the sheer quantity of blog-writing over so much time in a searchable index. There are bits missing here and there, and I'm determined to fill those bits in -- but the archive goes from October 7, 1994 at 11:27AM to the present day. A lot of stuff happened in that time, and some of it happened right here. I hope someday it proves to be a useful resource to people studying this period, with the usual caveat, assuming the human species survives. 😄

I'm sure there's better search software out there, but no one else has the sheer quantity of blog-writing over so much time in a searchable index. There are bits missing here and there, and I'm determined to fill those bits in -- but the archive goes from October 7, 1994 at 11:27AM to the present day. A lot of stuff happened in that time, and some of it happened right here. I hope someday it proves to be a useful resource to people studying this period, with the usual caveat, assuming the human species survives. 😄

item.description: Because the weather has been delightful here the last few days, I'm afraid I got no work done this week. I basically gave up today and spent time in the sun, reading, listening to music, went for a walk, did some shopping, took a long nap in the afternoon. I guess I was overdue for some downtime. It is a wonderful time of year, winter truly is over. We will still get some coldish weather, no doubt, but the glory of Catskills summer is coming soon. It's the best place to be in the summer.

source:outline.text: Because the weather has been delightful here the last few days, I'm afraid I got no work done this week. I basically gave up today and spent time in the sun, reading, listening to music, went for a walk, did some shopping, took a long nap in the afternoon. I guess I was overdue for some downtime. It is a wonderful time of year, winter truly is over. We will still get some coldish weather, no doubt, but the glory of Catskills summer is coming soon. It's the best place to be in the summer.

item.description: If Twitter had peered with other Twitter-like systems then they never would have had to develop and pay for content moderation. It's *possible* this is factored into Musk's plan. File this under "silos are expensive to run."

source:outline.text: If Twitter had peered with other Twitter-like systems then they never would have had to develop and pay for content moderation. It's *possible* this is factored into Musk's plan. File this under "silos are expensive to run."

item.description: One more thing -- the NBA Playoffs are here! And while my Knicks are not in contention this year, it does have the feel of an unusually good year. One reason it's so cool, no LeBron James! Hopefully at some point he'll stop trying to form superteams and finish his career with humility and grace, away from contention. I am rooting for teams with stars who have never won a championship, notably the Phoenix Suns and Chris Paul. I'm also glad to see the Warriors are back in the mix with the same big three and no Kevin Durant, who I will be rooting against every time he takes the court. I hope Boston blows the Nets out so that embarassment for the great city of New York is over for another year. Maybe they want him back in Oklahoma? I'm interested to see if James Harden can get it together to have a good long run, and while he has never won a championship, hmmm, I don't know. He played on the Nets this year, and for that reason I question his motivations. I do not like artificially created superteams designed to win championships. And of course they rarely do. So hopefully that chapter of the NBA will be over. One thing for sure sports is not arithmetic, esp not basketball.
